Award.AwardTitle: Stochastic Modeling of Post-Transcriptional Regulation of Gene Expression in Bacteria
Award.AbstractNarration: In this project the PI will develop quantitative stochastic models for modulation of gene expression by post-transcriptional regulation using a combination of analytical approach and stochastic simulations. The specific aims are to: 1) Develop an analytical framework for modeling intrinsic noise in gene expression focusing on post-transcriptional regulation by proteins. 2) Develop analytical and computational models for post-transcriptional regulation of gene expression by small RNAs. 3) Model post-transcriptional regulation of gene expression by the quorum sensing (QS) and carbon storage regulator (CsrA) pathways. The project will contribute several significant results to the theoretical framework for interpretation and analysis of experiments focusing on stochastic effects in gene expression. The exact results obtained will connect mRNA and protein distributions with general models of gene expression. The interdisciplinary aspects of the proposed research will lead to important advances in biological research. The proposed modeling of the QS and the CsrA regulatory networks will provide important insight into coordination and coregulation of gene expression by these pathways. At a broader level, the proposed research will contribute to a quantitative understanding of cellular pathways in which posttranscriptional regulation plays a critical role. The project will involve mentoring physics and biology students in interdisciplinary research on biological systems. In addition to training the graduate and undergraduate students performing the research, the proposed work will modernize an existing course in biological physics with the integration of results from current research into the coursework. All course material and computer programs developed during the course of the proposed work will be made freely available to the scientific community via Web interfaces thereby accelerating the pace of discovery. The results obtained during the course of the proposed research will be important inputs in guiding strategies aimed at controlling the QS and CsrA pathways.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the fundamental problems in biology is the identification of molecular mechanisms that give rise to differences, i.e. phenotypic variations, among individuals. Phenotypic variation is generally attributed to changes in genetic or environmental factors. However, in several cases (e.g. bacterial persistence, HIV-1 viral infections and cancer), phenotypic variations are observed even among genetically identical cells in homogeneous environments. Such phenotypic differences within isogenic populations can be critical for survival of the cell population under extreme stress. Recent research indicates that such non-genetic individuality can arise due to intrinsic stochasticity in the process of gene expression. Furthermore, advances in genomic technologies (e.g. RNA-seq) have increasingly highlighted the importance of non-coding RNAs in the regulation of critical cellular functions. Correspondingly, there is a need for quantitative modeling of stochastic gene expression and its regulation by non-coding RNAs in diverse cellular processes. The focus of this project has been on developing an analytical framework for stochastic modeling of gene expression and its post-transcriptional regulation by non-coding RNAs with applications to bacterial regulatory networks.

 

The project outcomes have contributed many significant advances to current research in the field. Some highlights from the project research include:

 

1)  Development of a novel mapping approach (Fig. 1) based on stochastic thinning of Poisson arrivals that leads to exact solutions for protein distributions in widely-used stochastic models of gene expression.

Reference: Phys Rev E, 87, 042720 (2013)

 

2) Obtaining the first exact steady-state solutions for stochastic models of gene expression with bursting and feedback (Fig. 2). The results obtained have diverse applications ranging from synthetic biology to modeling stochasticity in HIV-1 viral infections.

Reference: Physical Review Letters, 113, 268105, (2014)

 

3) Applications of queueing theory to obtain analytical expressions for moments in stochastic models of gene expression with complex promoter-based regulation. The results obtained can be used to develop protocols for determining key gene expression parameters based on measurements of moments of mRNA/protein distributions.

References:  1) Phys. Rev. E., 82, 021901 (2010),

                        2) Phys. Rev. Lett., 106, 058102 (2011),

                        3) PLoS Comp. Biol. (2015) 

 

4) Development and analysis of stochastic models of gene expression with post-transcriptional regulation by non-coding RNAs.The results obtained have provided insights into interplay between post-transcriptional regulation and stochasticity in gene expression and how non-coding RNAs can be used to control noise in gene expression circuits.
